conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to apply the principles of mechanics, specifically Newton's second law, to find the frictional force \( \mu \) and the angle \( \theta \).
The image shows a suitcase with wheels that can be pushed or pulled on the ground.

The suitcase has a total mass of 15 kg, and the passenger pulls it with an oblique upward pull to achieve uniform motion on horizontal ground. The minimum pull is 90 N, the angle between the pull and the horizontal is \( \theta \), and gravitational acceleration is \( g = 10 \text{ m/s}^2 \).
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, with the ratio being \( \mu \).

Identify the forces involved: The force \( F \) is the upward pull exerted by the passenger, the gravitational force \( G \) is the downward force due to gravity, and the frictional force \( N \) opposes the motion of the suitcase.

Use the principle of equilibrium: The sum of the forces in the horizontal direction must be zero \( F \cos \theta = G \), and the sum of the forces in the vertical direction must also be zero \( F \sin \theta = mg \).
Substitute the given values: \( F = 90 \text{ N} \), \( G = 15 \text{ kg} \times 10 \text{ m/s}^2 = 150 \text{ N} \), and \( m = 15 \text{ kg} \).

Since \( \mu \) is the ratio of the frictional force to the supporting force, and the frictional force is proportional to the supporting force, \( \mu \) is the same as the ratio of \( \sin \theta \) to \( \cos \theta \).
